item.title: How our brains track where we and others go
item.description: A new study reveals how your brain navigates places and monitors someone else in the same location. The findings suggest that our brains generate a common code to mark where other people are in relation to ourselves.

item.title: Disposable surgical masks best for being heard clearly when speaking, study finds
item.description: Researchers have published the results of a new study evaluating the acoustic effects of face masks on speech. The team tested medical masks, disposable surgical masks, masks with clear plastic windows around the mouth, and homemade and store-bought cloth masks made of different fabric types and numbers of layers.

item.title: Perfect transmission through barrier using sound
item.description: A research team has for the first time experimentally proved a century old quantum theory that relativistic particles can pass through a barrier with 100% transmission.

item.title: Conifers can be green because of a photosynthetic short-cut
item.description: How can conifers that are used, for example, as Christmas trees, keep their green needles over the boreal winter when most trees shed their leaves? Science has not provided a good answer to this question but now an international team of scientists has deciphered that a short-cut in the photosynthetic machinery allows the needles of pine trees to stay green.

item.title: Similar factors cause health disparities in cancer, COVID-19
item.description: The same societal factors that have caused worse outcomes in cancer for some minority populations are now causing disparities in COVID outcomes. Potential policy changes could help improve outcomes for both diseases.

item.title: With COVID exacerbating superbug threat, researchers ID new weapon
item.description: Researchers have discovered a compound capable of pushing through barriers used by Gram-negative bacteria to resist antibiotics, damaging the bugs and preventing them from spreading.

item.title: Cost-effective hood reduces aerosol exposures to patients, otolaryngologists
item.description: A new study evaluates the efficacy of a prototype device that can be used during common otolaryngologic procedures that generate significant aerosols and droplets.

item.title: Secondary bloodstream infections associated with severe COVID-19
item.description: People with severe COVID-19 and a secondary blood infection were significantly sicker upon hospital admission, had longer hospital stays and poorer outcomes, according to a new study.

item.title: New mammogram measures of breast cancer risk could revolutionize screening
item.description: World-first techniques for predicting breast cancer risk from mammograms could revolutionize breast screening by allowing it to be tailored to women at minimal extra cost.

item.title: Model predicts where ticks, Lyme disease will appear next in Midwest states
item.description: By drawing from decades of studies, scientists created a timeline marking the arrival of black-legged ticks, also known as deer ticks, in hundreds of counties across 10 Midwestern states. They used these data - along with an analysis of county-level landscape features associated with the spread of ticks - to build a model that can predict where ticks are likely to appear in future years.

item.title: Birds: Competition for mates leads to a deeper voice than expected based on size
item.description: Competition for mates leads to a deeper voice than expected based on size.

item.title: Why an early start is key to developing musical skill later in life
item.description: Is there, as some have suggested, a developmental period early in life when the brain is especially receptive to musical training? The answer, according to new research, is probably not.

item.title: New electron microscopy technique offers first look at previously hidden processes
item.description: Researchers have developed a new microscopy method that allows scientists to see the building blocks of 'smart' materials being formed at the nanoscale.

item.title: The brain's protein factories at work
item.description: Protein synthesis is a finely tuned process in the cell by macromolecules known as ribosomes. Which regulators are responsible for controlling protein synthesis in the brain? To address this question, researchers studied the structure of the brain's ribosomal complexes in great detail. The team was able to identify a new factor which is also involved in controlling brain development.

item.title: Mouse-controlled mouse helps researchers understand intentional control
item.description: Researchers have devised a brain machine interface (BMI) that allows mice to learn to guide a cursor using only their brain activity. By monitoring this mouse-controlled mouse moving to a target location to receive a reward, the researchers were able to study how the brain represents intentional control.

item.title: Chemists synthesize 'flat' silicon compounds
item.description: Chemists have synthesized extremely unusual compounds. Their central building block is a silicon atom. Different from usual, however, is the arrangement of the four bonding partners of the atom, which are not in the form of a tetrahedron around it, but flat like a trapezoid. This arrangement is usually energetically extremely unfavorable, yet the molecules are very stable.

item.title: In shaky times, focus on past successes, if overly anxious, depressed
item.description: The more chaotic things get, the harder it is for people with clinical anxiety and/or depression to make sound decisions and to learn from their mistakes. On a positive note, overly anxious and depressed people's judgment can improve if they focus on what they get right, instead of what they get wrong, suggests a new study.

item.title: Fluvial mapping of Mars
item.description: It took fifteen years of imaging and nearly three years of stitching the pieces together to create the largest image ever made, the 8-trillion-pixel mosaic of Mars' surface. Now, the first study to utilize the image in its entirety provides unprecedented insight into the ancient river systems that once covered the expansive plains in the planet's southern hemisphere.

item.title: Environmental effects of purchasing, consuming mislabeled fish
item.description: Seafood is the world's most highly traded food commodity, and reports of seafood mislabeling have increased over the past decade. However, proof of the environmental effects of mislabeled seafood has been scant as has research. So, researchers analyzed the impact of seafood mislabeling on marine population health, fishery management effectiveness, and habitats and ecosystems in the United States, the world's largest seafood importer.

item.title: A powerful computational tool for efficient analysis of cell division 4D image data
item.description: A research team has developed a novel computational tool that can reconstruct and visualize three-dimensional (3D) shapes and temporal changes of cells, speeding up the analyzing process from hundreds of hours by hand to a few hours by the computer. Revolutionizing the way biologists analyze image data, this tool can advance further studies in developmental and cell biology, such as the growth of cancer cells.

item.title: Surgery may offer survival advantage in certain metastatic breast cancers
item.description: Surgery, in addition to treatments like chemotherapy and radiation therapy, may increase the length of survival for metastatic breast cancer patients, according to researchers.

item.title: Extracting energy from manure to meet peak heating demands
item.description: Cornell University is developing a system to extract energy from cattle manure to meet the campus's peak demands for heat in the winter months. Scientists involved with the project give a detailed analysis of the issues required to make this work, including scientific, economic, and energy policy considerations.

item.title: Pregnant women in third trimester unlikely to pass SARS-CoV-2 infection to newborns
item.description: Pregnant women who are infected with SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, during the third trimester are unlikely to pass the infection to their newborns, new research suggests. The study followed 127 pregnant women who were admitted to Boston hospitals during the spring of 2020. Among the 64 pregnant women who tested positive for SARS-CoV-2, no newborns tested positive for the virus.

item.title: Hand-held device measures aerosols for coronavirus risk assessment
item.description: Understanding aerosol concentrations and persistence in public spaces can help determine infection risks. However, measuring these concentrations is difficult, requiring specialized personnel and equipment. Now, researchers demonstrate that a commercial hand-held particle counter can be used for this purpose and help determine the impacts of risk-reducing measures, like ventilation improvements.

item.title: Community spread of COVID-19 tied to patient survival rates at area hospitals
item.description: Discovering wide variation in hospitals' COVID-19 survival rates, researchers found that the levels of novel coronavirus in the surrounding community was likely the driving factor.

item.title: Masks not enough to stop COVID-19's spread without distancing, study finds
item.description: Wearing a mask may not be enough to prevent the spread of COVID-19 without social distancing. Researchers tested how different types of mask impacted the spread of droplets that carry the coronavirus when we cough or sneeze. Every material tested dramatically reduced the number of droplets that were spread. But at distances of less than 6 feet, enough droplets to potentially cause illness still made it through several of the materials.

item.title: Even after long-term exposure, bionic touch does not remap the brain
item.description: A new study by neuroscientists demonstrates that the brain does not remap itself even with long-term bionic limb use, posing challenges for the development of realistic prosthetic limbs.

item.title: Slow start of plate tectonics despite a hot early Earth
item.description: Scientists present important new constraints showing that plate tectonics started relatively slow, although the early Earth's interior was much hotter than today.

item.title: Ancient DNA sheds light on the peopling of the Mariana Islands
item.description: Compared to the first peopling of Polynesia, the settlement of the Mariana Islands in the Western Pacific, which happened around 3,500 years ago, has received little attention. Researchers have now obtained answers to long debated questions regarding the origin of the first colonizers of the Marianas and their relationship to the people who initially settled in Polynesia.

item.title: Pandemic and forthcoming stimulus funds could bring climate targets in sight -- or not
item.description: The lockdowns that resulted from the COVID-19 pandemic have reduced greenhouse gas emissions. However, in the recovery phase, emissions could rise to levels above those projected before the pandemic. It all depends on how the stimulus money that governments inject into their economies is spent. A team of scientists has quantified how different recovery scenarios may affect global emissions and climate change.

item.title: How a large protein complex assembles in a cell
item.description: A team of researchers has developed a method that allows them to study the assembly process for large protein complexes in detail for the first time. As their case study, the biologists chose one of the largest cellular complexes: the nuclear pore complex in yeast cells.

item.title: A new species of mammal may have been found in Africa's montane forests
item.description: A research team has discovered a tree hyrax in the Taita Hills, Kenya, which may belong to a species previously unknown to science.

item.title: Scientists invent glue activated by magnetic field
item.description: Scientists have developed a new way to cure adhesives using a magnetic field.

item.title: Droughts, viruses and road networks: Trends that will impact our forests
item.description: A new study assembled an array of experts to highlight major trends that will impact the world's forests, and the people living around them, in the decade ahead. These trends include drought, viral outbreaks and vast infrastructure expansions across the globe. According to the researchers, a global strategy for human-nature interaction must be developed if we intend on ensuring the survival of both.

item.title: Brain gene expression patterns predict behavior of individual honey bees
item.description: An unusual study that involved bar coding and tracking the behavior of thousands of individual honey bees in six queenless bee hives and analyzing gene expression in their brains offers new insights into how gene regulation contributes to social behavior.

item.title: Japanese art technique inspires new engineering technique
item.description: A team of engineers is using ideas taken from paper-folding practices to create a sophisticated alternative to 3D printing.

item.title: Liquid bandage detects tissue oxygenation without the drawbacks of wired oximeters
item.description: A paint-on, transparent bandage containing phosphorescent materials reads the amount of oxygen reaching transplanted tissue -- a critical component of a transplant's success. Existing oximeter technology is complicated to use, restricts patients' movements, and is subject to false alarms. The first human trial of the liquid bandage in women undergoing breast reconstruction after cancer found that it performed as well as a wired oximeter device, the current clinical standard.

item.title: A blazar in the early universe
item.description: Observations with the continent-wide Very Long Baseline Array (VLBA) reveal previously unseen details in a jet of material ejected from the core of a galaxy seen as it was when the universe was only about 7% of its current age.

item.title: Bio-inspired endoscope provides 3D visible and near-infrared images simultaneously
item.description: Researchers have developed a new bio-inspired medical endoscope that can acquire 3D visible light and near-infrared fluorescence images at the same time. It features an optical design that combines the high-resolution 3D imaging of human vision with the mantis shrimp's capability to simultaneously detect multiple wavelengths of light.

item.title: 'Soft' nanoparticles give plasmons new potential
item.description: Scientists couple gold nanoparticles with soft polymers that pull energy from the gold's plasmonic response to light. That energy can then be used to catalyze chemical reactions.

item.title: Increased meat consumption associated with symptoms of childhood asthma
item.description: Substances present in cooked meats are associated with increased wheezing in children, researchers report.

item.title: New imaging method views soil carbon at near-atomic scales
item.description: The Earth's soils contain more than three times the amount of carbon than is found in the atmosphere, but the processes that bind carbon in the soil are still not well understood.

item.title: Controlling cardiac waves with light to better understand abnormally rapid heart rhythms
item.description: Over 300,000 people die each year in the US due to sudden cardiac death. In many cases, sudden cardiac death is caused by abnormally rapid heart rhythms called tachycardias, which means the heart cannot pump adequate blood to the body. In Chaos, researchers use mice to study tachycardias and find there are intrinsic mechanisms that exist in heart tissue that they hypothesize lead to the self-termination of rapid cardiac rhythm.

item.title: New drug combination could improve glucose and weight control in diabetes
item.description: Scientists have shown that adding an experimental cancer drug to a widely used diabetes treatment improves blood glucose control and weight loss in mice, according to a new study.

item.title: Cannabis use blunts stress reactivity in female rats
item.description: Female rats that inhaled vaporized cannabis daily for a month developed a blunted physiological response to stress, according to a new study. In contrast, male rats that were provided access to the same potency of cannabis over the same 30-day window did not experience any physiological changes in how they responded to a stressful situation.

item.title: Bumblebees lacking high-quality habitat have higher pathogen loads
item.description: Bumblebees found in low-quality landscapes -- characterized by a relative lack of spring flowers and quality nesting habitat -- had higher levels of disease pathogens, as did bumblebees in areas with higher numbers of managed honey bee hives, according to scientists.

item.title: Key clues to understanding the death of stars
item.description: New research has found that by studying all three 'flavors' involved in a supernova, they've unlocked more clues as to how and why stars die.

item.title: Anti-diarrhea drug drives cancer cells to cell death
item.description: In cell culture, loperamide, a drug commonly used against diarrhea, proves effective against glioblastoma cells. A research team has now unraveled the drug's mechanisms of action of cell death induction and - in doing so - has shown how this compound could help attack brain tumors that otherwise are difficult to treat.

item.title: A groggy climate giant: Subsea permafrost is still waking up after 12,000 years
item.description: After the Last Glacial Maximum some 14,000 years ago, rising temperature melted glaciers and ice caps worldwide. Over thousands of years, sea levels rose by more than 400 feet (130 meters).

item.title: Frozen: Cutting-edge technology reveals structures within cells
item.description: Temperatures of minus 196 degrees Celsius enable high-resolution imaging of the cell's interior. Researchers are thus able to show for the first time how the active form of a protein complex plays critical roles in cell motility and other important biological functions look like.

item.title: Scientists discover mutations associated with early onset dementia
item.description: Scientists have announced a significant advance in our understanding of an early onset form of dementia that may also progress our understanding of conditions such as Alzheimer's disease. Adult onset Leukoencephalopathy with axonal Spheroids and Pigmented glia (ALSP) is an ultra-rare condition that manifests initially with psychiatric and behavioural changes in patients followed by a rapid progression of dementia in the third or fourth decade of life.

item.title: Neuroscientists isolate promising mini antibodies against COVID-19 from a llama
item.description: Researchers have isolated a set of promising, tiny antibodies, or 'nanobodies,' against SARS-CoV-2 that were produced by a llama named Cormac. Preliminary results suggest that at least one of these nanobodies, called NIH-CoVnb-112, could prevent infections and detect virus particles by grabbing hold of SARS-CoV-2 spike proteins. In addition, the nanobody appeared to work equally well in either liquid or aerosol form, suggesting it could remain effective after inhalation.

item.title: Antibiotics for C-sections effective after umbilical cord clamped
item.description: Antibiotics for cesarean section births are just as effective when they're given after the umbilical cord is clamped as before clamping - the current practice - and could benefit newborns' developing microbiomes, according to new research. The study, by far the largest of its kind, challenges current recommendations for antibiotic use. Administering antibiotics after clamping does not increase the risk of infection at the site of C-section incisions, the study concludes.

item.title: Biotech cotton key to eliminating devastating pest from US and Mexico
item.description: A collaboration between the University of Arizona, cotton growers, and government and industry partners eradicated the pink bollworm -- one of the world's most damaging crop pests -- from the United States and Mexico.

item.title: Deep, slow-slip action may direct largest earthquakes and their tsunamis
item.description: Megathrust earthquakes and subsequent tsunamis that originate in subduction zones like Cascadia -- Vancouver Island, Canada, to northern California -- are some of the most severe natural disasters in the world. Now a team of geoscientists thinks the key to understanding some of these destructive events may lie in the deep, gradual slow-slip behaviors beneath the subduction zones. This information might help in planning for future earthquakes in the area.

item.title: Hormone metabolites found in feces give researchers new insight into whale stress
item.description: Fecal samples are an effective, non-invasive tool for monitoring gray whale reproduction, stress and other physiological responses.

item.title: Light signal emitted during photosynthesis used to quickly screen crops
item.description: Researchers have revealed a new approach to estimate the photosynthetic capacity of crops to pinpoint their top-performing traits and speed up the plant screening process, according to a new study.

item.title: When light and atoms share a common vibe
item.description: Scientists demonstrate a state of vibration that exists simultaneously at two different times. They evidence this quantum superposition by measuring the strongest class of quantum correlations between light beams that interact with the vibration.

item.title: Ancient wolf pup mummy in Yukon permafrost from 57,000 years ago
item.description: While water blasting at a wall of frozen mud in Yukon, Canada, a gold miner made an extraordinary discovery: a perfectly preserved wolf pup that had been locked in permafrost for 57,000 years. The remarkable condition of the pup, named Zhùr by the local Tr'ondëk Hwëch'in people, gave researchers a wealth of insights about her age, lifestyle, and relationship to modern wolves.

item.title: New engine capability accelerates advanced vehicle research
item.description: In the quest for advanced vehicles with higher energy efficiency and ultra-low emissions, researchers are accelerating a research engine that gives scientists and engineers an unprecedented view inside the atomic-level workings of combustion engines in real time.

item.title: Nociceptive nerves regulate haematopoietic stem cell mobilization
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03057-y

Stimulation of pain-sensing neurons, which can be achieved in mice by the ingestion of capsaicin, promotes the migration of haematopoietic stem cells from the bone marrow into the blood.
item.dc:title: Nociceptive nerves regulate haematopoietic stem cell mobilization

item.title: Chromothripsis drives the evolution of gene amplification in cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03064-z

Chromothripsisa process during which chromosomes are shattereddrives the evolution of gene amplification and subsequent drug resistance in cancer cells.
item.dc:title: Chromothripsis drives the evolution of gene amplification in cancer

item.title: Molecular basis of nucleosomal H3K36 methylation by NSD methyltransferases
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03069-8

Cryo-electron microscopy structures of the nucleosome-bound NSD2 and NSD3 histone methyltransferases reveal the molecular basis of their histone modification activity, and show how mutations in these proteins can lead to oncogenesis.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03050-5

The net PKA activities in each class of spiny projection neuron in the nucleus accumbens of the mouse are dichotomously modulated by asynchronous positive and negative dopamine signals during different phases of learning.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03074-x

A class of compounds with a dual mechanism of actiondirect targeting of IspH and stimulation of cytotoxic ?? T cells to enhance pathogen clearanceare active against multidrug-resistant bacteria.

item.title: A genetic history of the pre-contact Caribbean
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03053-2

Ancient DNA reveals genetic differences between stone-tool users and people associated with ceramic technology in the Caribbean and provides substantially lower estimates of population sizes in the region before European contact.

item.title: Mastering Atari, Go, chess and shogi by planning with a learned model
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03051-4

A reinforcement-learning algorithm that combines a tree-based search with a learned model achieves superhuman performance in high-performance planning and visually complex domains, without any knowledge of their underlying dynamics.

item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3029-7

By combining the use of photoswitchable photoinitators and intersecting light beams, objects and complex systems can be produced rapidly with higher definition than is possible using state-of-the art macroscopic volumetric methods.

item.title: Mechanism of EBV inducing anti-tumour immunity and its therapeutic use
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03075-w

Expression of the EpsteinBarr virus protein LMP1 in B cells increases expression ofand promotes T cell responses totumour-associated antigens, delineating a mechanism of infection-induced anti-tumour immunity, which could inform immune-based approaches to cancer treatment.

item.title: Plasmonic topological quasiparticle on the nanometre and femtosecond scales
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 23 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3030-1

Topological plasmonic spin textures are excited by shining light on a structured silver film, and imaging defines how these quasiparticle field and spin textures evolve on the nanometre and femtosecond scales.
item.dc:title: Plasmonic topological quasiparticle on the nanometre and femtosecond scales

item.title: Small-molecule inhibitors of human mitochondrial DNA transcription
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03048-z

Inhibitors of mitochondrial transcription that target human mitochondrial RNA polymerase provide a chemical biology tool for studying the role of mitochondrial DNA expression in a wide range of pathologies.
item.dc:title: Small-molecule inhibitors of human mitochondrial DNA transcription

item.title: Fat1 deletion promotes hybrid EMT state, tumour stemness and metastasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-03046-1

In mouse and human squamous cell carcinoma, loss of function of FAT1 promotes tumour initiation, malignant progression and metastasis through the activation of a hybrid epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition phenotype.
item.dc:title: Fat1 deletion promotes hybrid EMT state, tumour stemness and metastasis

item.title: Entanglement on an optical atomic-clock transition
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3006-1

A many-atom state of trapped 171Yb atoms that are entangled on an optical atomic-clock transition overcomes the standard quantum limit, providing a proof-of-principle demonstration towards entanglement-based optical atomic clocks.
item.dc:title: Entanglement on an optical atomic-clock transition

item.title: Creation of bladder assembloids mimicking tissue regeneration and cancer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3034-x

Multilayer 3D reconstitution of bladder stem cells with stromal cells enables recapitulation of the architecture and molecular functions of bladder tissue.
item.dc:title: Creation of bladder assembloids mimicking tissue regeneration and cancer

item.title: Self-assembly of a layered two-dimensional molecularly woven fabric
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 16 December 2020; doi:10.1038/s41586-020-3019-9

An anion and metal ion template is used to form woven polymer patches that are joined together by polymerization into a fully woven, two-dimensional, molecular patchwork.
item.dc:title: Self-assembly of a layered two-dimensional molecularly woven fabric

item.title: Apollo 8: Earthrise
item.description: This iconic picture shows Earth peeking out from beyond the lunar surface as the first crewed spacecraft circumnavigated the Moon.

item.title: Stellar Snowflake Cluster
item.description: The newly revealed infant stars appear as pink and red specks toward the center and appear to have formed in regularly spaced intervals along linear structures.

item.title: Stellar Jewel Box
item.description: Thousands of sparkling young stars are nestled within the giant nebula NGC 3603, one of the most massive young star clusters in the Milky Way Galaxy. NGC 3603, a prominent star-forming region in the Carina spiral arm of the Milky Way about 20,000 light-years away, reveals stages in the life cycle of stars.

item.title: A Great Conjunction Draws Near
item.description: The Moon, left, Saturn, upper right, and Jupiter, lower right, are seen after sunset with the Washington Monument, Thurs. Dec. 17, 2020, in Washington.

item.title: Entering the Martian Atmosphere with the Perseverance Rover
item.description: With its heat shield facing the planet, NASAs Perseverance rover begins its descent through the Martian atmosphere in this illustration.

item.title: Starry, Starry Night
item.description: The Hubble Space Telescope captured a crowd of stars that looks rather like a stadium darkened before a show, lit only by the flashbulbs of the audience's cameras.

item.title: Quasars Rip Across Galaxies Like Tsunamis
item.description: Using the unique capabilities of NASA's Hubble Space Telescope, a team of astronomers has discovered the most energetic outflows ever witnessed in the universe.

item.title: Educational CubeSats to Launch on Virgin Orbits LauncherOne Rocket
item.description: Ten NASA-sponsored CubeSats are preparing to fly on the agencys next Educational Launch of Nanosatellites (ELaNa) mission, making this the first payload carried by Virgin Orbits LauncherOne rocket.

item.title: 50 Years of Research Using Langley's 14 by-22-Foot Subsonic Wind Tunnel
item.description: Dec. 11, 2020, marks the 50th anniversary of NASAs Langley Research Centers 14x22 Subsonic Wind Tunnel.

item.title: Introducing the Artemis Astronauts
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence introduces NASA astronauts during a meeting of the National Space Council on Dec. 9, 2020.

item.title: 3D Printed Rocket Parts and the Future of Spacecraft
item.description: Future lunar landers might come equipped with 3D printed rocket engine parts that help bring down overall manufacturing costs and reduce production time.

item.title: NASA, Boeing Complete Series of Starliner Parachute Tests
item.description: NASA and Boeing have completed Starliners last parachute balloon-drop test designed to strengthen the spacecrafts landing system ahead of crewed flights.

item.title: Seeing the Station From Earth
item.description: The International Space Station is seen in this 13 second exposure as it flies over Arlington, Virginia, Sunday, Dec. 6, 2020.

item.title: Relaxing Inside the Space Station's Window to the World
item.description: JAXA and Expedition 64 astronaut Soichi Noguchi relaxes at the end of the work day inside the seven-windowed cupola on the International Space Station.

item.title: Awakening Newborn Stars
item.description: Lying inside our home galaxy, the Milky Way, this HerbigHaro object is a turbulent birthing ground for new stars in a region known as the Orion B molecular cloud complex, located 1,350 light-years away.

item.title: Earth May Be Surrounded by Hairy Dark Matter
item.description: This illustration shows Earth surrounded by theoretical filaments of dark matter called "hairs."

item.title: Carol Harrison: Seeing the Beauty in All Things
item.description: Carol Carol "Bird Song" Harrison is a a quality assurance specialist (QAS) working in the Mission Assurance Branch at NASA's Langley Research Center.

item.title: It's Black Hole Friday!
item.description: What is a black hole? A black hole is an astronomical object with a gravitational pull so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape it.

item.title: Kenneth Attocknie: Fulfilling a Dream
item.description: Kenneth Attocknie has worked as an engineer for more than two decades at NASA's Johnson Space Center.

item.title: Artemis I Stacks Up
item.description: The first of 10 pieces of the twin Space Launch System (SLS) rocket boosters for NASAs Artemis I mission was placed on the mobile launcher Saturday, Nov. 21, 2020.

item.title: Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich Launches to Monitor Global Ocean
item.description: The SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket carrying the Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich spacecraft lifts off from Space Launch Complex 4 at Vandenberg Air Force Base in California, Nov. 21, 2020.

item.title: Hubble Captures Cosmic Cinnamon Bun
item.description: Observed with the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, the faint galaxy featured in this image is known as UGC 12588.

item.title: Marcellus Proctor: Bring a Unique Perspective
item.description: Marcellus Proctor is an enrolled member of the Piscataway-Conoy Nation and the Assistant Chief in the Electrical Engineering Division at NASA Goddard .

item.title: SpaceX Crew Dragon Approaches Space Station
item.description: The SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft is pictured approaching the International Space Station for a docking.

item.title: Hubble Spies Galaxy through Cosmic Lens
item.description: This NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope image features the galaxy LRG-3-817, also known as SDSS J090122.37+181432.3.

item.title: Crew-1 Launches on Historic Journey
item.description: SpaceX's Falcon 9 launches Crew-1 to the space station on Sunday, Nov. 15, 2020.

item.title: Lauren Denson: Jumping for Joy
item.description: With a degree in computer engineering and computer science from the University of Southern California, Lauren Denson is now an quality engineer and supervisor at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

item.title: Hubble Catches a Cosmic Cascade
item.description: The galaxy UGCA 193, seen here by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, is a galaxy in the constellation of Sextans (The Sextant).

item.title: SpaceX Falcon 9 Rolls Out for Saturday Launch
item.description: Launch is scheduled for 7:49 p.m. EST on Saturday, Nov. 14, 2020.

item.title: Astronauts Launching on NASA's SpaceX Crew-1 Mission Arrive at Kennedy Space Center
item.description: NASA astronauts Shannon Walker, left, Victor Glover, second from left, Mike Hopkins, second from right, and Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) astronaut Soichi Noguchi, right, are seen as they speak to members of the media after arriving at the Launch and Landing Facility at NASAs Kennedy Space Center ahead of SpaceXs Crew-1 mission.

item.title: Preparing the Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich Satellite for Launch
item.description: The Sentinel-6 Michael Freilich ocean-monitoring satellite is being encapsulated in the SpaceX Falcon 9 payload fairing.

item.title: Aerospace Engineer Joseph Connolly
item.description: Joseph Connolly is an aerospace engineer at NASA's Glenn Research Center.

item.title: Our Sun's Glint Beams Off San Francisco
item.description: The crew aboard the International Space Station snapped this image of the Earth's limb, or horizon, with the Sun's glint beaming off the U.S. West Coast.

item.title: Raquel Redhouse: Small Spacecraft Systems Virtual Institute Technical Manager
item.description: Raquel Redhouse is member of the Navajo (Diné) Nation, a mother and an engineer.

item.title: Celebrating 20 Years on Station: Expedition 1
item.description: This is the official portrait of the Expedition 1 crew, the first humans to live aboard the International Space Station.

item.title: Night Aboard the Space Station
item.description: Night aboard the International Space Station can seemingly look like every spooky sci-fi movie you've ever seen.

item.title: Our Halloween Sun
item.description: Active regions on the sun combined to look something like a jack-o-lanterns face on Oct. 8, 2014.

item.title: 'Sprites' Frolic in Jupiter's Atmosphere
item.description: The lightning phenomenon known as a sprite depicted at Jupiter in this illustration.

item.title: NASA Astronaut Kate Rubins Casts Her Vote from Space
item.description: NASA astronaut Kate Rubins points to the International Space Station's "voting booth" where she cast her vote from space this month.

item.title: Jezero Crater Was a Lake in Mars' Ancient Past
item.description: This illustration shows Jezero Crater  the landing site of the Mars 2020 Perseverance rover.

item.title: Hubble Views a Galactic Waterfall
item.description: In this spectacular image captured by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope, the galaxy NGC 2799 (on the left) is seemingly being pulled into the center of the galaxy NGC 2798 (on the right).

item.title: Studying Aircraft Noise
item.description: An array of 960 microphones is seen here off the end of runway 11 at Boeings research facility near Glasgow, Montana.

item.title: Touching Down on Asteroid Bennu
item.description: On Tuesday, Oct. 20, 2020, NASAs OSIRIS-REx sample collection mission performed a successful Touch-And-Go (TAG) maneuver.

item.title: Neutron Stars Create Gold and Platinum in Their Wake
item.description: This illustration shows the hot, dense, expanding cloud of debris stripped from neutron stars just before they collided.

item.title: Orions Recently Installed Solar Array Wings
item.description: Two of Orions four recently installed solar array wings are exposed and surrounded by the panels that will protect it during launch and ascent.

item.title: Hubble Snaps a Special Stellar Nursery
item.description: This Hubble image shows a special class of star-forming nursery known as Free-floating Evaporating Gaseous Globules. Called frEGGs for short, these dark compact globules of dust and gas can give birth to low-mass stars.

item.title: Cliffs in Ancient Ice on Mars
item.description: Scientists have come to realize that, just below the surface, about one third of Mars is covered in ice.

item.title: NASA Astronaut Kate Rubins Prepares for Launch to Space Station
item.description: NASA astronaut Kate Rubins is seen as she has her Russian Sokol suit pressure checked as she and fellow crewmates prepare for their Soyuz launch to the International Space Station.

item.title: The Ghost Nebula
item.description: ?Powerful gushers of energy from seething stars can sculpt eerie-looking figures with long flowing veils of gas and dust.

item.title: The Iris Nebula
item.description: The beautiful, blushing Iris Nebula is unique amongst its counterparts.

item.title: Thumbs Up From Out of This World
item.description: ASA spacewalkers (from left) Bob Behnken and Chris Cassidy give a thumbs up during a spacewalk to install hardware and upgrade International Space Station systems.

item.title: Grappling With the Future
item.description: The tip of the Canadarm2 robotic arm, also formally known as the Latching End Effector, is pictured as the International Space Station soared over the South Pacific Ocean .

item.title: Overcoming Hurricanes and Earthquakes to Get an Experiment to the Space Station
item.description: Camila Morales-Navas conducts final preparations on the Electrochemical Ammonia Removal system prior to parabolic flight testing.

item.title: Antares Rocket Launches to the Space Station
item.description: An Northrop Grumman Antares rocket, with the companys Cygnus spacecraft aboard, launches at 9:16 p.m. EDT, Friday, October 2, 2020, from t NASA's Wallops Flight Facility in Virginia.

item.title: Hubble Captures Galactic Glamour Shot
item.description: This stunning image by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope features the spiral galaxy NGC 5643 in the constellation of Lupus (the Wolf). NGC 5643 is about 60 million light-years away from Earth.

item.title: Satellite Captures Active Fires in the Western U.S.
item.description: Our Aqua satellite captured this composite visible and infrared image on Sep. 29, 2020, which shows that fires and smoke continue to dominate the landscape of the western U.S.

item.title: Retroreflectors: From Apollo to Mars
item.description: When Apollo 11 landed on the Moon, the crew brought devices with them called retroreflectors, which are essentially small arrays of mirrors.

item.title: Astronaut Serena M. Auñón-Chancellor Examines Her Eyes in Space
item.description: Astronaut Serena Auñón-Chancellor examines her eye with a Fundoscope aboard the International Space Station with remote support from doctors on the ground.

item.title: Soyuz MS-16 Spacecraft Docked to the Space Station
item.description: Pictured is the Soyuz MS-16 crew ship, currently docked to the International Space Station's Poisk module.

item.title: Hubble Shoots the Moon
item.description: This image from 1991 shows Earth's Moon, with its dark basaltic mare, clearly visible in great detail.
